decision_conditions: The row of cedars forms a boundary between 1 Linksway and 1a linksway. It can be seen from a number of different properties and also the golf course/footpath to the rear. As a result as a group this row of Cedars has a Moderate-to-high amenity value and it significantly contributes to the arboreal character of the Copsewood Estate (Area of Special Local Character). The trees also contribute to local biodiversity and form part of the area of mature, protected trees that help to provide a gradual transition of mature tree cover between the dwellings in the Copsewood Estate and the nearby Ruislip woods National Nature Reserve.

The reason for work supplied by the applicant is that one of the group fell over. There is no indication as to when this occurred and no arboricultural evidence provided as to why the falling over of one tree (from the site visit this was an end tree) means the remaining row requires removal.
Having regard to the reasons given for the proposed work, the work is un
The removal of deadwood, dangerous / hanging branches and ivy:  This does not require the formal consent of the Council.

Statutory crown lifting of trees: This does not require formal consent of the Council if the clearance only involves the removal of branches to give a separation between the footway and the tips of the lowest branches by up to 2.3m or the carriageway by up to 5.2m.
description: To fell one row of Cedar (G1 on application), within Area 1 on TPO 391. (The crown lifting of G2 on application to 2.5-3m is exempt)
